review.title: Solving Cooperative Reliability Games
review.abstract: Cooperative games model the allocation of profit from joint actions, following considerations such as stability and fairness. We propose the reliability extension of such games, where agents may fail to participate in the game. In the reliability extension, each agent only "survives" with a certain probability, and a coalition's value is the probability that its surviving members would be a winning coalition in the base game. We study prominent solution concepts in such games, showing how to approximate the Shapley value and how to compute the core in games with few agent types. We also show that applying the reliability extension may stabilize the game, making the core non-empty even when the base game has an empty core.

metadata.title: Solving Cooperative Reliability Games

sections.text: Cooperative games model the distribution of profits from joint actions based on factors such as stability and fairness. We propose extending the reliability of games in which agents may not participate in the game. In reliability enhancement, each player "survives" only with a certain probability, and the value of a coalition is the likelihood that its surviving members would be a victorious coalition in the base game. We examine prominent solutions in such games and show how to approach the shapley value and calculate the core in games with few agent types. We also show that applying reliability enhancement can stabilize the game so that the core is not empty, even if the base game has an empty core.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Consider a communication network linking a source and a destination, with each linkage controlled by a self-serving actor. Any linkage can fail, and if such linkages lead to the removal of all paths between source and destination, information cannot be sent between them. If we consider a planner aiming to maximize the likelihood of communication between source and destination, we can consider links outside of those linkages to have failed. Given a reward for achieving such linkages, which is a reasonable way of mapping that linkage between the actors, which linkages are the most critical? If the planner is allowed to use only a certain subset of the linkages, we can consider links outside of those linkages fallible.

sections.heading: 5 The Core of Reliability Games
sections.text: A natural question is how stability (in terms of strategic behavior) is affected as reliability declines. Although, in general, various effects are possible, we give a coherent answer in terms of convex and simple games. We show that if a simple or convex base game is stable (i.e. has a non-empty core), any reliability extension Hr has a non-empty core. sections.heading: 6 Conclusions and Related Work
sections.text: We proposed extending the reliability of cooperative games and discussed algorithms to solve this expansion. The solution of cooperative games was well studied and solutions were offered for various representations [10, 6, 8] and even for games with uncertain utility [21]. To our knowledge, this is the first paper to take into account arithmetic problems in cooperative games with uncertain rewards due to independent errors. Although calculating the Shapley value in various areas is difficult, several approaches have been proposed [10, 9, 11]. Our sampling approach to approximating the Shapley value [3], however, does not assume a method for calculating the characteristic function of a coalition in polynomic time (as mentioned, for the network reliability game is calculating the value of a coalition # P-hard). We also showed how to calculate the core when the base game has a veto agent and for limited reliability games has important differences between the core and its extension.
